item.title: Jack's Gelato Menus
item.description:
Bene’t Street (Sunday, 27/10/2024)

  • Vanilla
  • Roasted Hazelnut
  • House Mascarpone & Marsala Wine
  • Almond Friand, Raspberry Ripple
  • Girton Apple Sorbet (vegan)
  • Parsnip Cake
  • Coconut & Ube (vegan)
  • Strawberries & Cream
  • Blueberry & Thyme Sorbet (vegan)
  • Chocolate, Raspberry Ripple
  • Chai Masala
  • Sherry; Palo Cortado 30yr old (+£3)

All Saints (Sunday, 27/10/2024)

  • Banoffee
  • Milk & Manuka Honey
  • Canele de Bordeaux

  • Grilled Milk Chocolate
  • Lemon & Mint Sorbet (vegan)
  • Gooseberry (textured; skin and seed included)(vegan)
  • Coconut Ube (vegan)
  • Vanilla
  • Dark Chocolate & Sea Salt (vegan)
  • Strawberries & Aged Balsamic

All menu information is property of Jack’s Gelato. See my blog post for why I made this website.

item.title: A Faster Gelato
item.description: I love Jack’s Gelato. Unfortunately, their website’s menu sucks. So I fixed it.

item.title: Update Bot
item.description: uv is great! Unfortunately, it is not supported by Dependabot yet. I built a simple GitHub Actions workflow to act as a stop-gap until support is added.

item.title: Github Token Authentication
item.description:
A note on provenance:

I originally wrote this guide for the University of Warwick Computing Society to pre-empt common issues when authenticating to GitHub from the command line during academic workshops, such as Git Good.

Since I wrote the guide, I have switched from using personal access tokens to SSH keys for authentication. This incurs the slight annoyance of requiring SSH rather than HTTPS remotes, but avoids the requirement of storing plaintext tokens locally – instead using a password-protected SSH key. Additionally, on MacOS, the password can be stored in the user keychain, so is not prompted each time.

Why do I need to do this?

For ✨security✨…

From August 2021, GitHub announced they would not be allowing password authentication when using the command line to interact with github.com [1] .

item.title: Fixing EndeavourOS Boot Failures
item.description: This post enumerates a process which worked for me to repair an installation of EndeavourOS with full-disk encryption when it is unable to boot. It is also available as a gist.

item.title: The Mathematics of Lasagne
item.description:
Lasagne. What is it? Why is it? This talk seeks to obfuscate the answer to these questions.

Watch it on YouTube

item.title: About
item.description:
Hello there 👋 ! Welcome to my corner of the internet.

I’m currently studying at the University of Cambridge for an MPhil in Advanced Computer Science. I previously studied at the University of Warwick, and have spent some time as an academic officer at the University of Warwick Computing Society and as a CAD Design Verification intern at Apple.

In my free time, I sing in the Peterhouse Chapel Choir, always try to commute by bicycle instead of walking (irrespective of how short the journey is), and occasionally rock climb. When I have the time and opportunity, I also work on various side projects – some of which I finish!

item.title: Blog Canary
item.description:
In 1895, John Scott Haldane proposed bringing warm-blooded animals, most commonly canaries, into mines to detect high levels of carbon monoxide [1] . This worked because they would become sick (and stop singing) before the miners did. Because of this, “Canary in a coal mine” is commonly used as an idiom for something which warns people of danger.

This blog post is (in a very convoluted sense) a canary for my website, as it exercises the elements which can be embedded in a blog post. If I broke something in the server side rendering it will be messed up here, like a canary in a coal mine.

item.title: Hello There
item.description: For quite a while, I’ve been “working on” a personal website, letting perfect be the enemy of good and having nothing to show for it, but no more!
